segment.source: Deploying and debugging Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
segment.target: Deploying and debugging Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article guides you through the steps to target various deployment and debugging targets.
segment.target: This article guides you through the steps to target various deployment and debugging targets.

segment.source: Microsoft Visual Studio allows you to deploy and debug your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps on a variety of Windows 10 devices.
segment.target: Microsoft Visual Studio allows you to deploy and debug your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps on a variety of Windows 10 devices.

segment.source: Visual Studio will handle the process of building and registering the application on the target device.
segment.target: Visual Studio will handle the process of building and registering the application on the target device.

segment.source: Picking a deployment target
segment.target: Picking a deployment target

segment.source: To pick a target, navigate to the debug target dropdown next to the Start Debugging button and select which target you want to deploy your application to.
segment.target: To pick a target, navigate to the debug target dropdown next to the Start Debugging button and select which target you want to deploy your application to.

segment.source: After the target is selected, choose Start Debugging (F5) to deploy and debug on that target, or press Ctrl+F5 to just deploy to that target.
segment.target: After the target is selected, choose Start Debugging (F5) to deploy and debug on that target, or press Ctrl+F5 to just deploy to that target.

segment.source: Local Machine will deploy the application to your current development machine.
segment.target: Local Machine will deploy the application to your current development machine.

segment.source: This option is only available if your application's Target Platform Min. Version is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.
segment.target: This option is only available if your application's Target Platform Min. Version is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.

segment.source: Simulator will deploy the application to a simulated environment on your current development machine.
segment.target: Simulator will deploy the application to a simulated environment on your current development machine.

segment.source: This option is only available if your application's Target Platform Min. Version is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.
segment.target: This option is only available if your application's Target Platform Min. Version is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.

segment.source: Device will deploy the application to a USB connected device.
segment.target: Device will deploy the application to a USB connected device.

segment.source: The device must be developer unlocked and have the screen unlocked.
segment.target: The device must be developer unlocked and have the screen unlocked.

segment.source: An Emulator target will boot up and deploy the application to an emulator with the configuration specified in the name.
segment.target: An Emulator target will boot up and deploy the application to an emulator with the configuration specified in the name.

segment.source: Emulators are only available on Hyper-V enabled machines running Windows 8.1 or beyond.
segment.target: Emulators are only available on Hyper-V enabled machines running Windows 8.1 or beyond.

segment.source: Remote Machine will let you specify a remote target to deploy the application.
segment.target: Remote Machine will let you specify a remote target to deploy the application.

segment.source: More information about deploying to a remote machine can be found in Specifying a remote device.
segment.target: More information about deploying to a remote machine can be found in Specifying a remote device.

segment.source: Specifying a remote device
segment.target: Specifying a remote device

segment.source: C\# and Microsoft Visual Basic
segment.target: C\# and Microsoft Visual Basic

segment.source: To specify a remote machine for C\# or Microsoft Visual Basic apps, select Remote Machine in the debug target dropdown.
segment.target: To specify a remote machine for C\# or Microsoft Visual Basic apps, select Remote Machine in the debug target dropdown.

segment.source: The Remote Connections dialog will appear which will let you specify an IP Address or select a discovered device.
segment.target: The Remote Connections dialog will appear which will let you specify an IP Address or select a discovered device.

segment.source: By default, the Universal authentication mode is selected.
segment.target: By default, the Universal authentication mode is selected.

segment.source: To determine which authentication mode to use, see Authentication modes.
segment.target: To determine which authentication mode to use, see Authentication modes.

segment.source: To return to this dialog, you can open project properties and navigate to the Debug tab.
segment.target: To return to this dialog, you can open project properties and navigate to the Debug tab.

segment.source: From there, select Find…
segment.target: From there, select Find…

segment.source: next to Remote machine:
segment.target: next to Remote machine:

segment.source: To deploy an application to a remote PC, you will also need to download and install the Visual Studio Remote Tools on the target PC.
segment.target: To deploy an application to a remote PC, you will also need to download and install the Visual Studio Remote Tools on the target PC.

segment.source: See Remote PC instructions for full instructions.
segment.target: See Remote PC instructions for full instructions.

segment.source: C++ and JavaScript
segment.target: C++ and JavaScript

segment.source: To specify a remote machine target for a C++ or JavaScript UWP app, go to project properties by right clicking on the project in the Solution Explorer, and clicking Properties.
segment.target: To specify a remote machine target for a C++ or JavaScript UWP app, go to project properties by right clicking on the project in the Solution Explorer, and clicking Properties.

segment.source: Navigate to Debugging settings and change Debugger to launch to Remote Machine.
segment.target: Navigate to Debugging settings and change Debugger to launch to Remote Machine.

segment.source: Then fill in the Machine Name (or click Locate…
segment.target: Then fill in the Machine Name (or click Locate…

segment.source: to find one) and set the Authentication Type property.
segment.target: to find one) and set the Authentication Type property.

segment.source: After the machine is specified, you can select Remote Machine in the debug target dropdown to return to that specified machine.
segment.target: After the machine is specified, you can select Remote Machine in the debug target dropdown to return to that specified machine.

segment.source: Only one remote machine can be selected at a time.
segment.target: Only one remote machine can be selected at a time.

segment.source: Remote PC instructions
segment.target: Remote PC instructions

segment.source: To deploy to a remote PC, the target PC must have the Visual Studio Remote Tools installed.
segment.target: To deploy to a remote PC, the target PC must have the Visual Studio Remote Tools installed.

segment.source: The remote PC must also be running a version of Windows that is greater than or equal to your apps Target Platform Min. Version property.
segment.target: The remote PC must also be running a version of Windows that is greater than or equal to your apps Target Platform Min. Version property.

segment.source: Once you have installed the remote tools, you must launch the remote debugger on the target PC.
segment.target: Once you have installed the remote tools, you must launch the remote debugger on the target PC.

segment.source: To do this, search for Remote Debugger in the Start menu launch it, and if prompted allow the debugger to configure your firewall settings.
segment.target: To do this, search for Remote Debugger in the Start menu launch it, and if prompted allow the debugger to configure your firewall settings.

segment.source: By default, the debugger launches with Windows authentication.
segment.target: By default, the debugger launches with Windows authentication.

segment.source: This will require user credentials if the logged in user is not the same on both PCs.
segment.target: This will require user credentials if the logged in user is not the same on both PCs.

segment.source: To change it to No authentication, go to Tools Options in the Remote Debugger and set it to No Authentication.
segment.target: To change it to No authentication, go to Tools Options in the Remote Debugger and set it to No Authentication.

segment.source: Once the remote debugger is setup, you can deploy from your development machine.
segment.target: Once the remote debugger is setup, you can deploy from your development machine.

segment.source: For more information see the Remote Tools for Visual Studio download page.
segment.target: For more information see the Remote Tools for Visual Studio download page.

segment.source: Authentication modes
segment.target: Authentication modes

segment.source: There are three authentication modes for remote machine deployment:
segment.target: There are three authentication modes for remote machine deployment:

segment.source: Universal (Unencrypted Protocol): Use this authentication mode whenever you are deploying to a remote device that is not a Windows PC (desktop or laptop).
segment.target: Universal (Unencrypted Protocol): Use this authentication mode whenever you are deploying to a remote device that is not a Windows PC (desktop or laptop).

segment.source: Currently, this is only IoT devices.
segment.target: Currently, this is only IoT devices.

segment.source: Universal (Unencrypted Protocol) should only be used on trusted networks.
segment.target: Universal (Unencrypted Protocol) should only be used on trusted networks.

segment.source: The debugging connection is vulnerable to malicious users who could intercept and change data being passed between the development and remote machine.
segment.target: The debugging connection is vulnerable to malicious users who could intercept and change data being passed between the development and remote machine.

segment.source: Windows: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).
segment.target: Windows: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).

segment.source: Use this authentication mode when you have access to the credentials of the logged in user of the target machine.
segment.target: Use this authentication mode when you have access to the credentials of the logged in user of the target machine.

segment.source: This is the most secure channel for remote deployment.
segment.target: This is the most secure channel for remote deployment.

segment.source: None: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).
segment.target: None: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).

segment.source: Use this authentication mode when you have a test machine setup in an environment that has a test account logged in and you cannot enter the credentials.
segment.target: Use this authentication mode when you have a test machine setup in an environment that has a test account logged in and you cannot enter the credentials.

segment.source: Make sure the remote debugger settings are set to accept no authentication.
segment.target: Make sure the remote debugger settings are set to accept no authentication.

segment.source: Debugging options
segment.target: Debugging options

segment.source: On Windows 10, the startup performance of UWP apps is improved by proactively launching and then suspending apps in a technique called prelaunch.
segment.target: On Windows 10, the startup performance of UWP apps is improved by proactively launching and then suspending apps in a technique called prelaunch.

segment.source: Many applications will not need to do anything special to work in this mode, but some applications may need to adjust their behavior.
segment.target: Many applications will not need to do anything special to work in this mode, but some applications may need to adjust their behavior.

segment.source: To help debug any issues in these code paths you can start debugging the app from Visual Studio in prelaunch mode.
segment.target: To help debug any issues in these code paths you can start debugging the app from Visual Studio in prelaunch mode.

segment.source: Debugging is supported both from a Visual Studio project (Debug Other Debug Targets Debug Universal Windows App Prelaunch), and for apps already installed on the machine (Debug Other Debug Targets Debug Installed App Package, and check the box for Activate app with Prelaunch).
segment.target: Debugging is supported both from a Visual Studio project (Debug Other Debug Targets Debug Universal Windows App Prelaunch), and for apps already installed on the machine (Debug Other Debug Targets Debug Installed App Package, and check the box for Activate app with Prelaunch).

segment.source: For more information read about how to Debug UWP Prelaunch.
segment.target: For more information read about how to Debug UWP Prelaunch.

segment.source: You can set the following deployment options on the Debug property page of the startup project.
segment.target: You can set the following deployment options on the Debug property page of the startup project.

segment.source: Allow Network Loopback
segment.target: Allow Network Loopback

segment.source: For security reasons, a UWP app that is installed in the standard manner is not allowed to make network calls to the device it is installed on.
segment.target: For security reasons, a UWP app that is installed in the standard manner is not allowed to make network calls to the device it is installed on.

segment.source: By default, Visual Studio deployment creates an exemption from this rule for the deployed app.
segment.target: By default, Visual Studio deployment creates an exemption from this rule for the deployed app.

segment.source: This exemption allows you to test communication procedures on a single machine.
segment.target: This exemption allows you to test communication procedures on a single machine.

segment.source: Before submitting your app to the Windows Store, you should test your app without the exemption.
segment.target: Before submitting your app to the Windows Store, you should test your app without the exemption.

segment.source: To remove the network loopback exemption from the app:
segment.target: To remove the network loopback exemption from the app:

segment.source: On the C\# and Visual Basic Debug property page, clear the Allow Network Loopback check box.
segment.target: On the C\# and Visual Basic Debug property page, clear the Allow Network Loopback check box.

segment.source: On the JavaScript and C++ Debugging property page, set the Allow Network Loopback value to No.
segment.target: On the JavaScript and C++ Debugging property page, set the Allow Network Loopback value to No.

segment.source: Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts (C\# and Visual Basic) / Launch App (JavaScript and C++)
segment.target: Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts (C\# and Visual Basic) / Launch App (JavaScript and C++)

segment.source: To configure the deployment to automatically start a debugging session when the app is launched:
segment.target: To configure the deployment to automatically start a debugging session when the app is launched:

segment.source: On the C\# and Visual Basic Debug property page, check the Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts check box.
segment.target: On the C\# and Visual Basic Debug property page, check the Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts check box.

segment.source: On the JavaScript and C++ Debugging property page, set the Launch Application value to Yes.
segment.target: On the JavaScript and C++ Debugging property page, set the Launch Application value to Yes.
